briefOverview: The Lord instructs Newel Knight and his group after a broken covenant, directing them to leave and relocate toward Missouri while remaining humble and patient.
summary: The Lord affirms His authority and commands Newel Knight to remain firm in his appointed office. He calls the group to repent and be truly humble, noting that their covenant has been broken and is therefore void, pronouncing woe upon the offender and blessing upon those who kept the covenant. They are told to flee the land to avoid enemies, select a leader, arrange needed funds, and travel west to Missouri near the borders of the Lamanites. After arriving, they are to seek their livelihood like other people until the Lord prepares a place for them. He urges patience in tribulation and promises His coming and rest for those who seek Him early.
externalContext: This revelation is historically connected to the Colesville, New York, branch of early Latter-day Saints, led by Newel Knight, who had relocated to Thompson, Ohio, in 1831. Under the recently introduced law of consecration, land usage arrangements were made but then revoked when a prior landholder reneged, leaving the group displaced. Social and legal pressures against the new movement in Ohio also heightened the urgency for relocation. References to the “borders of the Lamanites” reflect early Church plans to gather in western Missouri near the frontier of Indian Territory, which by mid-1831 would be associated with the establishment of Zion in Jackson County.
externalReferences: “Alpha and Omega” echoes Revelation 1:8, affirming Christ’s eternal identity. The severe warning—“better for him that he had been drowned in the depth of the sea”—parallels Jesus’ teaching about causing offense (Matthew 18:6; cf. Mark 9:42). The promise, “I come quickly; and my reward is with me,” reflects Revelation 22:12. The directive to go to the “borders of the Lamanites” connects with earlier instructions about missionary work and gathering in that region (Doctrine and Covenants 28:8; 32:2–3).
practicalQuestions: When promises or agreements collapse, how can I remain faithful and humble rather than embittered?
What steps can my community take to act prudently and unitedly when facing hostility or displacement?
How do I balance seeking ordinary employment with waiting on God to “prepare a place” for me?
In what ways can I support appointed leaders while also sharing in practical responsibilities like finances and logistics?
What habits help me cultivate patience in tribulation while living in hope of Christ’s promised return?
uncertainAreas: The text does not identify the specific individual who broke the covenant; historical attribution comes from outside sources. The instruction to “appoint whom you will to be your leader, and to pay moneys for you” leaves unspecified the exact arrangements. The phrase “seek ye a living like unto men” is somewhat ambiguous about duration and scope.
